newsitem.title: USA: Ralph Lauren stock poised for gains.
newsitem.headline: Ralph Lauren stock poised for gains.

text.p: Polo Ralph Lauren Corp sold shares for $26 each Wednesday in the second largest initial public offering this year, raising roughly $767 million.
Stock in the fashion designer is expected to jump nearly $5 when it begins trading Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange, analysts say.

The offering will make an even richer man out of Ralph Lauren, a former necktie salesman from the Bronx whose original name is Ralph Lifshitz, and is expected to spur other designers to take their fashion houses to Wall Street.
"This is the biggest payday in the history of Seventh Avenue," said Alan Millstein, editor and publisher of the Fashion Report, referring to the traditional home of the fashion industry.
Despite the enormous size of the offering, even portfolio managers at some of the top U.S. investment banks were not sure if they could get a piece of the red-hot deal.
"I don't even know if I'm getting an allocation," said Arden Armstrong, portfolio manager at Miller Anderson & Sherrerd LLP, which manages over $41.4 billion of assets.

Polo's strong brand name, its established menswear line, a growing line of womenswear and opportunities to grow around the globe are all drawing Wall Street's eye. Analysts also say its broad product line protects its from "fashion disasters".
Wall Street has mixed feeling about fashion houses -- Gucci Group more than tripled from its IPO, while Donna Karan International Inc. fell more than 50 percent.

"In fashion, things are quixotic. Success is ephemeral. But Ralph Lauren is not a designer -- he's a businessman first. He doesn't sit around with a sketch pad. That makes him a better bet for the investment community," said Millstein.
The company has also branched out from traditional apparel to sell products such as towels, sheets, bedspreads and even paint.
Despite Polo's strengths, some analysts have knocked the deal, saying the price was too steep, especially when compared with Tommy Hilfiger Corp..

But Armstrong said she was willing to pay top dollar: "This is an expensive deal, but it's worth it. The P/E (price to earnings) ratio is higher than Tommy, and Tommy's growing faster, but this is a much more mature deal. They have strong cash flow and a stable and mature business."

Manish Shah, editor of the IPO Maven, expects the stock to follow Gucci upwards. "It's expensive, but fundamentals are good." He recommends holding the stock until it reaches $35 if it was bought at the $26 IPO price. But on the open market, he only recommends buying below $32. He considers the stock overvalued above $35.

The initial price of the shares exceeded their estimated cost of $22 to $25. Of the total 29.5 million shares, the company itself will sell 9.4 million, raising $244.4 million. But the lion's share will be sold by Lauren and Goldman Sachs, which held a 28 percent stake before the IPO.
"But if the business is so real and its so great, why is Goldman getting out? That always leaves a bad taste in the mouth," said Manish Shah.
Millstein, of the Fashion Report, said the deal may lure other world class designers to Wall Street.

"This IPO made more money than they could have fantasized. It will cause them to lose sleep. This is an industry inhabited by the most jealous, thin-skinned egotistical people in the world. Polo will absolutely speed up any ideas held by Calvin Klein or Gianni Versace about going public," he said.
Millstein said the designer with the best prospects and the most established empire was Italian designer Giorgio Armani.
"But it would be a long shot. He's a very private person."
The offering makes this the best week yet for IPOs, raising $1.87 billion so far and beating the $1.67 billion record held by the week of May 23, according to Securities Data Co.
